September 2008  –  May 2010  (1 year 9 months) [product management, marketing management, user experience, customer development, brand management, business development] 
 
MojaMix.com is an internet startup about choice. It is a web platform that brings mass-customization to the food industry. We focused on the $10Bn US breakfast cereal market. At MojaMix.com you can create your own breakfast cereal, granola or trail mix. There are literally trillions of different combinations - to make your own mix and personalize the package with what is important for you. It was featured on Techcrunch, Fast Company, Thrillist, Daily Candy, Forbes.com and over 30 blogs. 
 
MojaMix aims to do what Netflix and Dell did to their respective product categories: bring choice and personalization to radically change the way consumers interact with the product. 
 
MojaMix was acquired by private investors in May 2010.  
 
* Led the company from concept to positive cash flow and acquisition. 
* Acted as product manager and defined product features and user experience, resulting in 94% of customers rating the site ‘Very intuitive’ and ‘Simple to use’ web application. 
* Directed marketing campaigns and PR, leading to detailed media coverage from Techcrunch, Fast Company, Thrillist, Daily Candy, Forbes.com and over 30 blogs. 
* Recruited and managed team of product marketing, software and front-end engineers. 
* Identified opportunities by using agile customer development methods, incorporating insights from experiments, metrics analysis, and in-depth customer feedback. 
 
Note: MojaMix was bootstrapped while the co-founders were master students at Berkeley and was one of the few companies admitted in the UC Berkeley incubator. Summary As a Product Manager at Google, I lead pricing & conversion funnel optimization for our same-day delivery business. Previously, I led our m-commerce apps to facilitate easy on-the-go shopping; I've also focused on shifting Brand marketing dollars online by creating a platform for rich, beautiful and measurable ads. 
 
My diverse experience across engineering, finance, lieutenant to VP / Directors, and product management positions me uniquely to a) map market opportunities b) build a team to execute vision with speed & excellence c) measure impact and forecast growth d) read early indicators & pivot as necessary. 
 
Tenacity, speed to market, extending influence without power, attention to detail, cross-team collaboration and structured effective communication are my strengths. I am very passionate about technology, and how it can influence millions of lives around the world. Experience Lead Monetization Product Manager, Google Express Google June 2014  – Present (1 year 2 months) Mountain View Google Express launched as a free trial service and gained traction quickly. The next step in our growth is attracting loyal paying shoppers. I led the launch of GSX's membership offering at $10/month or $95/year. Members get free same-day or overnight delivery on eligible orders over $15, priority access to delivery windows and ability to share their benefits with a household member.  
 
Key achievements: 
+ Launched paid membership offering and grandfathered in legacy users, closely managing new user sign up rate at xx%, legacy user conversion rate at xx% and churn rate at xx% 
+ Led a team of ~70 across engineering, ux, marketing, legal, ops, biz dev, finance, biz ops and pr, getting rigorous key stakeholder buy in on proposal and timelines 
+ Optimized membership flows through A/B tests to minimize drop-off rates in acquisition and retention funnels 
+ Won VP spot bonus for team management and speed to market Mobile Product Manager, Google Shopping Express Google February 2014  –  April 2015  (1 year 3 months) Mountain View Google Shopping Express helps users discover local shopping the easy way—no lines, no lists, no schlepping. We offer same day delivery from the local stores users love: Target, Walgreens, Costco and many more.  
 
Impact: 
+ Established year long mobile strategy and drove features to improve our shopper conversion funnel, growing mobile usage from almost zero to over 50% of order volume 
+ Spearheaded improvements in mobile search results pages to facilitate quick discovery & add-to-cart 
+ Sketched user touchpoint strategy, and launched system notifications to inform users about the status of their order 
+ Launched platform reporting dashboard to create visibility into mobile's growth, advocated heavy investment in mobile to become m-commerce market leaders, thereby growing the team 2x 
+ Led end-to-end app redesign conferring to Material Design principles, with the goal of creating delightful shopping moments on-the-go 
 
Check out our iOS app at https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/google-express/id690229094. Product Manager, Brand Display Ads Google March 2012  –  February 2014  (2 years) Mountain View 15 years ago, Google invented the "click" for online ads, and revolutionized the industry by bringing measurability to the art of advertising. While direct response dollars flow freely through the ecosystem, brand dollars are still tied up in traditional media like TV and print. The next revolution is to help brands transition to multiple screens where their users are spending their time; it will come with the invention of the "click" for branding! 
 
Key results: 
+ Led team of 65 without authority to develop $100M brand display business, with 50% penetration in top 200 brands 
+ Scaled rich media ads by streamlining purchase process down to 5 steps and reducing turn-around-time by 70% 
+ Pioneered 9 rich cross-screen interactive ad formats, capturing extra 20% queries from touch devices 
+ Spearheaded goal based buying strategy to optimize toward maximum user engagement with brand messages, resulting in 35% better engagement rates, at 25% lower cost-per-user-engagement 
+ Launched Engagement Developer Program to harvest 3rd party expertise in creative innovation, with 4 partners 
 
Check out our brand advertising product here: http://www.google.com/think/products/engagement-ads.html Display Ads Chief of Staff Google August 2011  –  December 2013  (2 years 5 months) Mountain View Display Ads started out with 2 simple goals: a) to bring advertisers' message to exactly the right customers wherever they are online and b) to keep the internet free by creating alternative monetization opportunities for millions of publishers. While achieving these goals, the Display Ads team at Google aims to transform online advertising from invasive and annoying to relevant and useful for all our users. 
 
I served as Chief of Staff to the VP, Google Display Ads with the following impact: 
+ Formulated annual strategy for multi-billion display ads business across team of 1000+ engineers & product managers.  
+ Drafted annual and quarterly objectives and periodically reviewed key performance indicators to ensure delivery on big bets 
+ Led resource planning across display ads to prioritize projects to double down in, and identify those to be killed 
+ Managed display ads’ launch pipeline and analyzed sustainable revenue and intangible impact, resulting in zero sensitive launches going through without thorough review 
+ Orchestrated weekly strategy reviews across engineering, product, sales and operations leaders, cycling through big bets to identify and remove any roadblocks, make market positioning decisions or craft competitive response  
+ Evaluated 6 prospective deals with partners, resulting in 2 successful acquisitions; oversaw their integration plans Financial Analyst Google June 2009  –  August 2011  (2 years 3 months) Mountain View Revenue forecasting is a key component of planning short, medium and long term roadmaps for the company, especially when there are several macro factors outside our control. The revenue forecasting team at Google is extremely analytical and rigorous in their prediction models and serve as a key stakeholder in strategic decisions across the company.  
 
Impact: 
+ Built rigorous short and long term revenue forecasts for 6 (of 10) product lines, maintaining variance within +/-2% 
+ Identified key metrics to indicate health of product lines, and led weekly executive reviews of these metrics 
+ Analyzed & presented business drivers, regional variability, impact of sales compensation and economic trends 
+ Set quarterly quotas for 10000+ sales team, incentivizing them to meet stretch targets for strategic high-growth areas 
+ Drafted first P&L view of 6 product lines, empowering executives with their net impact to Google’s bottom line Finance MBA Intern Google May 2008  –  August 2008  (4 months) Mountain View, California Internships at Google are an opportunity to explore its diverse culture: the healthy disregard for the impossible, asking for forgiveness rather than permission, thinking big, no, bigger. And while having fun, this is a great opportunity for students to discover if they'd like to come back full-time. 
 
As a Financial Analyst MBA intern: 
+ Analyzed (decaying) impact of product launches on Google's revenue streams; build robust system to capture impact of launches into revenue forecasts, improving forecast time by 83% and saving 1.5 hours per cycle 
+ Led team of 3 engineers to develop an internal system to track financial and strategic impacts of product launches 
+ Found a full time role at the company :) Software Engineer Infosys Technologies Ltd June 2006  –  July 2007  (1 year 2 months) Bangalore, India Infosys is an Indian technology consulting firm focused on building enterprise solutions. Maintaining strong relationships with clients is Infosys's mantra: happy clients = repeat business. My team serviced Reed Elsevier's educational publishing division. Our client was satisfied with our work: we won a repeat $2.5M at the end of our project! 
 
Besides web development, I designed and developed a defect tracking system to reduce turnaround time for most common defects in amateur code. I also led training sessions for new hires, thus bridging the steep ramp up from college to productive engineers. Product Manager, Brand Display Ads Google March 2012  –  February 2014  (2 years) Mountain View 15 years ago, Google invented the "click" for online ads, and revolutionized the industry by bringing measurability to the art of advertising. While direct response dollars flow freely through the ecosystem, brand dollars are still tied up in traditional media like TV and print. The next revolution is to help brands transition to multiple screens where their users are spending their time; it will come with the invention of the "click" for branding!

+ Launched Engagement Developer Program to harvest 3rd party expertise in creative innovation, with 4 partners

Experience Associate Product Manager - Google Fit Google August 2014  – Present (1 year) Mountain View, California I am the product manager for the Google Fit app. 
 
My recent responsibilities include: 
+ Leading the app through its initial launch, in the process defining our mission, strategy, minimum viable product and responding to internal feedback to get us to a launch-ready state.  
+ Leading prioritization efforts, establishing product vision and roadmaps and driving decision-making across leadership, engineering, design, marketing, PR, legal and release teams through multiple product iterations on our mobile/tablet Android applications, Android Wear application and web offering.  
+ Growing the app from initial launch to over 7 million users in 6 months.

My responsibilities included:  
+ Leading prioritization efforts, establishing product vision and roadmaps and drove decision-making across leadership, engineering, design, marketing, PR, legal and release teams through multiple product iterations on google.com/flights. 
 
Top launches include the following:

+ Allowing users to save flights and share them with their travel partners 
+ Putting flight prices right into our date selector so users can be price-conscious from the start 
+ Working through technical constraints to develop a travel exploration feature where a user can get flight prices from their origin to top cities around the world 
+ Grouping flights results in commuter markets (e.g. LA -> NYC) for easier viewing, similar to transit schedules (also received patent for the UI) 
+ Launching the product in 20+ new languages and introducing currency selection for international users 
+ Evangelizing and representing the product both within the company as well as outside conferences and events such as being a keynote speaking at the Travel Executive Forum 
+ Revamping our PR and marketing efforts 
+ Actively recruiting for the Google, participating as a panelist at several external events and giving presentations at universities

Summary I am a Product Manager in Stockholm where I lead Google's WebRTC platform. Real Time Communication (RTC) and Product Management are my areas of expertise and interest. 
 
I moved to Sweden in 1997 to start a PhD. There, I helped I co-found Marratech AB in 1998, developing software for multi user video communication. At Marratech, I got to work across several functions: Starting a company, setting up engineering, marketing, business plans and investor relations.  
 
In 2007, after a year of consulting, our software code was sold to Google and key employees joined the search engine company.  
 
My first project was within the Google Talk team, where we launched the Gmail voice and video chat software, used by millions within Gmail, iGoogle and Orkut. 
 
I also started the project that developed into Google Hangouts video communication platform. I also started the GVC project, which resulted in Chromebox for Meetings later on.  
 
In 2009, I lead the acquisition of Global IP Solutions (GIPS). The goal of this was to give voice, video and data communication capabilities to the web, something we called WebRTC. WebRTC is a Javascript API that enables Peer to Peer audio, video and data communication between web browsers, iOS and Android.  
 
= Google is hiring in Sweden = 
Google has an important engineering presence in Stockholm:  
 
• Hangouts: 
We provide the scalable, reliable infrastructure for RTC at Google. It is used by Hangouts (audio, video and chat) and realtime messaging. These include: Chrome Sync, Google Play and others. 
 
• Chrome WebRTC 
We work on signal processing components for audio, video and bandwidth estimation. We are also responsible for the the javascript APIs in Blink, driving the W3C and IETF and integrating the signal processing bits in Chrome.  
 
• Chromebox for Meetings 
We work on integrating Hangouts inside this innovative device, enabling enterprise users to communicate at a fraction of the price of traditional equipment.

I moved to Sweden in 1997 to start a PhD. There, I helped I co-found Marratech AB in 1998, developing software for multi user video communication. At Marratech, I got to work across several functions: Starting a company, setting up engineering, marketing, business plans and investor relations.  
 
In 2007, after a year of consulting, our software code was sold to Google and key employees joined the search engine company.  
 
My first project was within the Google Talk team, where we launched the Gmail voice and video chat software, used by millions within Gmail, iGoogle and Orkut. 
 
I also started the project that developed into Google Hangouts video communication platform. I also started the GVC project, which resulted in Chromebox for Meetings later on.  
 
In 2009, I lead the acquisition of Global IP Solutions (GIPS). The goal of this was to give voice, video and data communication capabilities to the web, something we called WebRTC. WebRTC is a Javascript API that enables Peer to Peer audio, video and data communication between web browsers, iOS and Android.  
 
= Google is hiring in Sweden = 
Google has an important engineering presence in Stockholm:  
 
• Hangouts: 
We provide the scalable, reliable infrastructure for RTC at Google. It is used by Hangouts (audio, video and chat) and realtime messaging. These include: Chrome Sync, Google Play and others. 
 
• Chrome WebRTC 
We work on signal processing components for audio, video and bandwidth estimation. We are also responsible for the the javascript APIs in Blink, driving the W3C and IETF and integrating the signal processing bits in Chrome.  
 
• Chromebox for Meetings 
We work on integrating Hangouts inside this innovative device, enabling enterprise users to communicate at a fraction of the price of traditional equipment.

8) Global strategy that effectively lit up markets such as Brazil (end of 2014) with a number of forms of payment.
